Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Australia
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Thomas Heider of the University of Connecticut to conduct a research project in Biological Sciences during the summer of 2013 at the University of Melbourne in Melbourne Australia. The project title is "Wallabase: Jump starting the tammar wallaby genome database." The host scientist is Professor Marilyn Renfree.

A key challenge in genomics is distinguishing the regions of DNA that are essential for development and disease from those that are nonfunctional. The genomics community is rapidly coming to appreciate the power of marsupial comparative genetics for this task. Aided by extensive developmental and physiological data, the tammar wallaby has proven instrumental for the study of developmental processes that are conserved among mammals. To make this information more accessible to researchers, this project creates the genome database, Wallabase. Wallabase lowers the barriers that prevent the broader scientific community from utilizing marsupials in deciphering the human genome. In particular, researchers trying to identify novel antimicrobials, those in the dairy industry and clinicians utilizing the unique development of the wallaby will greatly benefit from the accessibility of the information on Wallabase.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, there will be additional sections on Wallabase that will educate the general public about the use of wallabies in research and about the importance of comparative studies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The tammar wallaby (Macropus eugenii) is an important emerging model organism in studying every gene in mammals. Comparing information about a gene in the tammar wallaby to a mouse or human allows for important insights into what that gene’s actual purpose is. With the ease at which mutations in a gene can be found and that the function of so many genes unknown, this type of comparison is a key tool that researchers can utilize to determine if a mutation occurred in a functional or nonfunctional part of a gene. The reason why the comparison to a marsupial like the tammar wallaby can be more informative than using an animal such as a cat, dog or pig is because of the evolutionary distance between marsupials and humans. The distance is great enough that it allows for nonfunctional aspects of a gene to change while close enough that the biology of the marsupial is similar enough that it is useful to understand the aspects of humans that distinguishes them from animals such as fish, birds or insects.

In addition to understanding what is important about a gene, there are several unique characteristics of the tammar wallaby that would allow researchers to better understand cellular and developmental processes. All of its genes are organized into only eight different pieces of DNA rather than 23 different pieces of DNA for humans. This much smaller number makes it easier to track how a cell divides, which is important in understanding the progression of cancer. Furthermore, stages of development in the tammar wallaby that correspond to unborn stages in mice and human occur in the pouch in the tammar wallaby, which allows researchers to study these stages without having to sacrifice animals to study and allows for researchers to track the progression of a particular developmental defect in a single animal. Related to that fact is that the immune system does not develop until long after birth, when the tammar wallaby young has already been exposed to may infectious disease in the pouch, yet it does not succumb to diseases. A better understanding of why this occurs could lead to the identification of novel antimicrobials.

The major problem in using the tammar wallaby to study genes is that the information has not been organized to the same extent as information about other widely studied animals like mice, humans or even worms. This means that using the tammar wallaby requires a significant amount of extra time to find where information is, analyze it and share it with other researchers. This is the problem that WallaBase addresses by collecting and organizing all of the information previously generated by the initial genome project. Once published, this centralization of information will dramatically increase the efficiency of researchers who already study genes using the tammar wallaby. Additionally, it will allow researchers who focus on understanding genes using mice or humans to easily access information from the tammar wallaby about the genes and mutations that they are interested in.

The East Asia & Pacific Summer Institutes (EAPSI) fellowship allowed me to travel to Australia to better understand the needs of the tammar wallaby research community so that the services that WallaBase provides will actually match the needs. Being able to experience firsthand what happens in multiple different labs studying the tammar wallaby provided irreplaceable knowledge about how to best design WallaBase. For the development of young scientists, this program is very effective, it provided a framework that I was able to utilize to learn how to design a successful collaborative project.
